micros.name: Early Humor Landing
micros.description: Light humor lands early and the buyer joins in, creating fast comfort.

micros.name: Buyer Mirrors Tone
micros.description: Buyer adopts your energy or style, signaling alignment and safety.

micros.name: Shared Frame Formation
micros.description: You and the buyer start speaking from the same mental model.

micros.name: Smooth Energy Matching
micros.description: Your pace and tone fit the buyer's pace and tone naturally.

micros.name: Psychological Safety Signal
micros.description: Buyer speaks openly and corrects you without hesitation.

micros.name: Natural Back and Forth Rhythm
micros.description: The conversation flows like a real dialogue rather than an interview.

micros.name: Shared Context Snap
micros.description: You reference a shared experience or cultural touchpoint that creates instant connection.

micros.name: Authority Framing by Buyer
micros.description: Buyer signals that you are already seen as an advisor or expert.

micros.name: Buyer Language Adoption
micros.description: You use the buyer's own words to reinforce clarity and connection.

micros.name: Buyer Narrative Expansion
micros.description: Buyer gives longer, more detailed answers because they feel heard.

micros.name: Expertise Mirror
micros.description: Buyer reflects back your expertise or credibility signals.

micros.name: Vocabulary Handoff
micros.description: Buyer starts using your frameworks, terms, or language patterns.

micros.name: Newsletter Pre-Sale
micros.description: Buyer mentions they've read your content or already know your approach.

micros.name: Buyer Voluntary Vulnerability
micros.description: Buyer reveals something sensitive without being pushed.

micros.name: Empathy Reflection
micros.description: You capture and reflect the buyer's emotional tone accurately.

micros.name: Buyer Motivator Identification
micros.description: You uncover the personal stakes behind the business issue.

micros.name: Loss Aversion Confirmation
micros.description: You identify what the buyer fears losing if things stay the same.

micros.name: Desire Framing
micros.description: You capture what the buyer is hoping to gain or feel.

micros.name: Emotional Weight Acknowledgement
micros.description: You validate that the issue has real emotional weight for the buyer.

micros.name: Topic Hopping
micros.description: You bounce across issues with no cohesion or thread.

micros.name: Meandering Structure
micros.description: The call feels scattered, circular, or without clear direction.

micros.name: Talking Through Buyer
micros.description: You jump in too early or cut the buyer off mid-thought.

micros.name: Letting Buyer Drift Unchecked
micros.description: You let the buyer wander for minutes without steering back.

micros.name: Forced Warmth
micros.description: Your attempts at friendliness feel unnatural or try-hard.

micros.name: Over Eagerness
micros.description: You sound too hungry or excited, creating buyer pressure.

micros.name: Ignoring Buyer Tone
micros.description: You miss cues about buyer mood, comfort level, or engagement.

micros.name: Energy Mismatch
micros.description: Your energy is too high or too low for the buyer's comfort zone.

micros.name: Business First Jump
micros.description: You skip rapport and jump directly into business talk.

micros.name: Abrupt Agenda Start
micros.description: You launch into the agenda without any warm-up or calibration.

micros.name: Ignoring Emotional Cues
micros.description: You push forward on business without reading buyer emotional state.

micros.name: No Rapport Stage
micros.description: You eliminate or rush through the rapport-building phase entirely.

micros.name: Clean Problem Summary
micros.description: You restate the problem in a way that feels exact and clarifying to the buyer.

micros.name: Problem Excavation
micros.description: You dig past symptoms into the real operational or strategic problem.

micros.name: Impact Excavation
micros.description: You uncover the business or emotional cost behind the problem.

micros.name: Strategic Depth Link
micros.description: You connect daily pain to larger strategic goals or company priorities.

micros.name: Context Mapping
micros.description: You learn the surrounding environment, constraints, or dynamics shaping the problem.

micros.name: Clear Outcome Reframe
micros.description: You help the buyer see a new possibility or framing they hadn't considered.

micros.name: Signal Based Relevance Delivery
micros.description: You tailor your message or question based on something the buyer just revealed.

micros.name: Story to Strategy Bridge
micros.description: You connect a buyer's anecdote or story to a strategic implication.

micros.name: Pricing Intervention
micros.description: You diagnose and call out underpricing or value misalignment directly.

micros.name: Future State Painting
micros.description: You help the buyer envision a better outcome or future state clearly.

micros.name: Criteria Surfacing
micros.description: Buyer explains how they will judge or evaluate possible solutions.

micros.name: Decision Journey Discovery
micros.description: You identify who decides, how they decide, what the timeline is.

micros.name: Budget Realism Probe
micros.description: You test whether budget expectations match reality and surface constraints.

micros.name: Buyer Connects Dots Unprompted
micros.description: Buyer makes their own connections or realizations without you leading them.

micros.name: Conceptual Over Explanation
micros.description: You turn simple ideas into complicated lectures or abstract frameworks.

micros.name: Feature Drowning
micros.description: You overwhelm the buyer with information, features, or details they didn't ask for.

micros.name: Misaligned Story Choice
micros.description: You tell a story or example that doesn't fit the buyer's world or problem.

micros.name: Premature Pitch
micros.description: You talk about your solution before understanding the buyer's problem.

micros.name: Non-Listening Question
micros.description: You ask a question that shows you weren't listening to the buyer's last answer.

micros.name: Over Customization Without Buy-In
micros.description: You start designing custom solutions before the buyer has agreed to the core approach.

micros.name: Over Solutioning
micros.description: You solve problems the buyer hasn't prioritized or doesn't care about.

micros.name: Generosity Trap
micros.description: You give so much free value that the buyer doesn't need to buy.

micros.name: Advice Avalanche
micros.description: You deliver full step-by-step solutions during the discovery call.

micros.name: Giving Full Roadmap
micros.description: You lay out the entire execution plan before the buyer has committed.

micros.name: Pretend Strategy Session
micros.description: You conduct what feels like a paid strategy session for free.

micros.name: Step by Step Teaching
micros.description: You walk the buyer through how to solve their problem without you.

micros.name: Surface Pain Looping
micros.description: You repeat the surface-level problem without digging deeper.

micros.name: No Impact Excavation
micros.description: You never uncover business or emotional consequences of the problem.

micros.name: No Strategic Depth
micros.description: You fail to connect pain to broader company goals or priorities.

micros.name: No Criteria Discovery
micros.description: You have no idea how the buyer will choose a solution or what matters to them.

micros.name: Detached Question Sequencing
micros.description: Your questions feel random, scripted, or disconnected from buyer responses.

micros.name: Problem Switching Without Closure
micros.description: You jump to new problems without resolving or understanding the previous one.

micros.name: Premature Diagnosis
micros.description: You assume you know the problem before hearing enough from the buyer.

micros.name: Evaluation Fog
micros.description: You don't understand how the buyer will evaluate options or make decisions.

micros.name: Risk Profile Unexplored
micros.description: You don't understand what risks the buyer is willing or unwilling to take.

micros.name: Clear Framing
micros.description: You explain why a question, direction, or topic matters before exploring it.

micros.name: Story Deployment
micros.description: You use a simple, relevant story that makes the value or concept tangible.

micros.name: Controlled Feature Use
micros.description: You only mention features that directly serve the current problem or conversation.

micros.name: One Problem One Promise
micros.description: You keep the narrative focused on one key pain point and one clear outcome.

micros.name: Team Visibility Engine
micros.description: You create transparency that makes the buyer's work or progress visible to their team.

micros.name: Expansion Slide
micros.description: You plant seeds for future expansion or upsell naturally in the conversation.

micros.name: Agenda Abandonment
micros.description: You start with structure then let the call drift away from the plan.

micros.name: Time Mismanagement
micros.description: You run out of time for the most important part of the call.

micros.name: Priority Landscape Ignored
micros.description: You don't understand what the buyer cares about most or what's urgent.

micros.name: Buying Process Ignored
micros.description: You don't explore how the buyer actually makes purchasing decisions.

micros.name: No Timeline Mapping
micros.description: You don't establish when the buyer needs to solve this or make a decision.

micros.name: No Permission Asking
micros.description: You shift topics or go deeper without checking in with the buyer.

micros.name: Undefined Ownership
micros.description: It's unclear who is responsible for next steps or decisions.

micros.name: Hidden Decider Missed
micros.description: You don't identify or involve the actual decision-maker.

micros.name: Buyer Led Sequencing
micros.description: The buyer controls the order and flow of topics while you follow.

micros.name: No Conversation Reset
micros.description: You let the conversation go off track without steering it back.

micros.name: Premature Solution
micros.description: You jump to solution mode before discovery is complete.

micros.name: Early Feature Talk
micros.description: You start describing features or capabilities too early in the conversation.

micros.name: Assumption Based Prescribing
micros.description: You prescribe solutions based on assumptions rather than discovery.

micros.name: Solving Before Stakeholder Clarity
micros.description: You propose solutions before understanding who's involved in the decision.

micros.name: Offer Drift
micros.description: Your offer or solution changes multiple times during the conversation.

micros.name: Promise Stack
micros.description: You keep adding promises or deliverables without clarifying the core offer.

micros.name: Misaligned Promise
micros.description: What you promise doesn't match what the buyer actually needs or asked for.

micros.name: Price Framing Before Value
micros.description: You introduce pricing before establishing clear value or differentiation.

micros.name: Permission Asking
micros.description: You check in before shifting topics or exploring sensitive areas.

micros.name: Permission Pattern
micros.description: You consistently ask for permission to proceed at key moments.

micros.name: Controlled Parking of Topics
micros.description: You defer off-track ideas gracefully without losing control.

micros.name: Risk Reduction Language
micros.description: You explicitly reduce perceived risk with language like 'you can cancel anytime.'

micros.name: Buyer Pulling Forward
micros.description: Buyer asks about next steps or shows eagerness on their own initiative.

micros.name: Clear Timeline Alignment
micros.description: You and the buyer share a realistic sense of timing and urgency.

micros.name: Agreement on Success Criteria
micros.description: You get explicit alignment on what success looks like.

micros.name: Micro Commitment Capture
micros.description: You secure small yeses that keep the conversation progressing.

micros.name: Next Step Precision
micros.description: You define exactly what happens next, who owns it, and when.

micros.name: Clean Decision Reflection
micros.description: You reflect the buyer's own criteria and stakes back to them clearly.

micros.name: No Clear Next Step
micros.description: The call ends with no assigned responsibility or timing for what happens next.

micros.name: Weak Close
micros.description: You don't confidently guide toward a decision path or commitment.

micros.name: Action Ambiguity
micros.description: Next steps are unclear, vague, or left undefined.

micros.name: No Confirmation of Interest
micros.description: You never explicitly test if the buyer is actually interested in moving forward.

micros.name: Late Bill Drop
micros.description: You mention price or terms at the very end without context or framing.

micros.name: Defensive Response
micros.description: You react poorly to buyer skepticism or objections.

micros.name: Over Reassurance
micros.description: You try too hard to comfort the buyer and lose credibility in the process.

micros.name: Pressure Spike
micros.description: Something you say increases buyer tension or creates resistance.

micros.name: Expertise Overcompensation
micros.description: You brag, name-drop, or posture to seem credible or smart.

micros.name: Credibility Erosion
micros.description: Your authority or trustworthiness decreases during the conversation.

micros.name: Hesitation Cascade
micros.description: Your uncertainty grows and becomes contagious to the buyer.

micros.name: Apology Overuse
micros.description: You apologize too often and weaken your authority or position.

micros.name: Uncertain Framing
micros.description: You present ideas as guesses or possibilities rather than confident leadership.

micros.name: Outcome Undersell
micros.description: You downplay your value, results, or impact.

micros.name: Confidence Overcompensation
micros.description: You try too hard to sound confident and lose trust in the process.

micros.name: Buyer Language Miss
micros.description: You fail to adopt or mirror the buyer's terminology and phrasing.

micros.name: Acronym Dumping
micros.description: You use jargon or acronyms the buyer doesn't understand.

micros.name: Industry Flex
micros.description: You show off industry knowledge in a way that creates distance.
